Award.AwardTitle: Student Transition, Achievement, Retention and Teaching

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Johnson State College in rural Vermont is developing its programs in Environmental and Health Science with scholarships for academically talented but financially needy students, many of whom are the first generation in their families to attend college. These programs work in partnerships with New England TRIO Upward Bound Math-Science projects in Vermont and have developed articulation agreements with community colleges, high schools, and other institutions of higher learning, so that students can have the maximum opportunity for retention in their majors and academic success. As a small school, Johnson State can offer individualized mentoring, opportunities for undergraduate research, and advising about graduate school and future careers in environmental science. This grant is co-funded through the Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Student Transition, Achievement, Retention, and Teaching (START) program provided academically talented, yet financially disadvantaged students, with appropriate opportunities to build skillsets that enabled them to do their best and most creative work. With enhanced advising, academic training, and opportunities for faculty-mentored research, most START scholars completed their degrees, minimized their college debt, and were better prepared for life after college. Two-thirds of the START scholars were the first in their families to obtain a college degree, two-thirds of the START scholars were female, and half of those who participated in this program (including all recent graduates and those who left the program) sought advanced degrees or found employment in the STEM field. Furthermore, the graduation rate for START scholars was 46 percentage points higher than the all-college rate.

The highly successful START Seminar, offered as a workshop, enabled students to develop the skills required to succeed in college and beyond. The activities cultivated improvement in note-taking, test-taking, presentation skills, critical reading, laboratory techniques, research methods, writing skills, mathematics, time management, the development of grant proposals, and preparation for participation in scientific conferences. The students’ learning experiences at Johnson State College were enriched through opportunities for faculty-mentored undergraduate research, and the development of interviewing skills, resumes, and applications in order to identify internship opportunities, find future employment or seek advanced degrees.

Student interests and dedication to learning were piqued through opportunities for faculty-mentored undergraduate research, and student participation in local, regional, national, and international conferences. START scholars presented their research i) to the Members of Congress at a Posters on the Hill event, ii) at National Council on Undergraduate Research annual meetings, iii) at the First World Congress on Undergraduate Research in Qatar, and iv) at approximately 35 local and regional conferences. START scholars also served the college community as leaders of the student government, academic coaches, club presidents, and as athletes. These students are effective ambassadors for Johnson State College and the Vermont State College System.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/26/2018
Modified by: Leslie H Kanat

The activities cultivated improvement in note-taking, test-taking, presentation skills, critical reading, laboratory techniques, research methods, writing skills, mathematics, time management, the development of grant proposals, and preparation for participation in scientific conferences. The students? learning experiences at Johnson State College were enriched through opportunities for faculty-mentored undergraduate research, and the development of interviewing skills, resumes, and applications in order to identify internship opportunities, find future employment or seek advanced degrees. Student interests and dedication to learning were piqued through opportunities for faculty-mentored undergraduate research, and student participation in local, regional, national, and international conferences.
